docs.lead_paragraph: Two Kennedys are facing off over competing versions of legislation that would provide more generous benefits to people with mental illness.

headline.main: Proposals for Mental Health Parity Pit a Father’s Pragmatism Against a Son’s Passion
headline.print_headline: Proposals for Mental Health Parity Pit a Father’s Pragmatism Against a Son’s Passion

docs.snippet: Two Kennedys are facing off over competing versions of legislation that would provide more generous benefits to people with mental illness.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's Kennedy versus Kennedy as two members of Congress from the same family face off over competing versions of legislation that would require many health insurance companies and employers to provide more generous benefits to people with mental illness. Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, Democrat of Rhode Island and chief sponsor of the House bill, has criticized as inadequate the Senate bill introduced by his father, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. Representative Kennedy is trying to mobilize mental health advocates to lobby for what he describes as ''the stronger of the two bills, the House bill.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The test, the counselor said, had come back positive. Katharine Moser inhaled sharply. She thought she was as ready as anyone could be to face her genetic destiny. She had attended a genetic counseling session and visited a psychiatrist, as required by the clinic. She had undergone the recommended neurological exam. And yet, she realized in that moment, she had never expected to hear those words.

headline.main: Facing Life With a Lethal Gene

docs.abstract: Article in series The DNA Age: Choosing to Know; Katharine Moser is part of vanguard of people at risk for Huntington's disease who are choosing to learn early through genetic testing what their future holds; raft of new DNA tests is revealing predispositions to all kinds of conditions, but little is known about what it is like to live with such knowledge; photos; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appellate panel ruled that the Union Pacific Railroad Company did not discriminate against its female employees because its insurance did not cover contraception used by men either.
